entities.title: Alexander Wilson (ornithologist)
entities.description: Alexander Wilson was a Scottish-American poet, ornithologist, naturalist, and illustrator. Identified by George Ord as the "Father of American Ornithology", Wilson is regarded as the greatest American ornithologist prior to Audubon.

heading: Births
txt: Stamford Raffles, English politician, founded Singapore (d. 1826)

entities.title: Stamford Raffles
entities.description: Sir Thomas Stamford Bingley Raffles, FRS was a British statesman, Lieutenant-Governor of the Dutch East Indies (1811–1816) and Lieutenant-Governor of Bencoolen (1818–1824), best known for his founding of modern Singapore and the Straits Settlements.

entities.title: Singapore
entities.description: Singapore, officially the Republic of Singapore, is a sovereign island city-state in maritime Southeast Asia. It lies about one degree of latitude north of the equator, off the southern tip of the Malay Peninsula, bordering the Straits of Malacca to the west, the Riau Islands (Indonesia) to the south, and the South China Sea to the east. The country's territory is composed of one main island, 63 s

heading: Births
txt: Maria Luisa of Spain (d. 1824)

entities.title: Maria Luisa, Duchess of Lucca
entities.description: Maria Luisa of Spain was a Spanish infanta, daughter of King Charles IV and his wife, Maria Luisa of Parma. In 1795, she married her first cousin Louis, Hereditary Prince of Parma. She spent the first years of her married life at the Spanish court where their first child, Charles, was born.

heading: Births
txt: William Hooker, English botanist and academic (d. 1865)

entities.title: William Jackson Hooker
entities.description: Sir William Jackson Hooker was an English botanist and botanical illustrator, who became the first director of Kew when in 1831 it was recommended to be placed under state ownership as a botanic garden. At Kew he founded the Herbarium and enlarged the gardens and arboretum. The standard author abbreviation Hook. is used to indicate this person as the author when citing a botanical name.

heading: Births
txt: María Isabella of Spain (d. 1846)

entities.title: María Isabella of Spain
entities.description: Maria Isabella of Spain was an infanta of Spain and Queen consort of the Two Sicilies.

heading: Births
txt: Nicholas I of Russia (d. 1855)

entities.title: Nicholas I of Russia
entities.description: Nicholas I reigned as Emperor of Russia, King of Poland and Grand Duke of Finland from 1825 until 1855. He was the third son of Paul I and younger brother of his predecessor, Alexander I. Nicholas inherited his brother's throne despite the failed Decembrist revolt against him. He is mainly remembered in history as a reactionary whose controversial reign was marked by geographical expansion, econom

heading: Births
txt: Henry Paget, 2nd Marquess of Anglesey (d. 1869)

entities.title: Henry Paget, 2nd Marquess of Anglesey
entities.description: Henry Paget, 2nd Marquess of Anglesey,, styled Lord Paget 1812 and 1815 and Earl of Uxbridge from 1815 to 1854, was a British peer and Whig politician. He served as Lord Chamberlain of the Household between 1839 and 1841.

heading: Births
txt: Louisa Caroline Huggins Tuthill, American author  (d. 1879)

entities.title: Louisa Caroline Huggins Tuthill
entities.description:
Louisa Caroline Huggins Tuthill was one of the most successful 19th-century American authors.
In addition to the first history of architecture published in the United States, History of Architecture from the Earliest Times (1848), she wrote numerous books for children and young adults.

heading: Births
txt: Albert von Kölliker, Swiss anatomist and physiologist (d. 1905)

entities.title: Albert von Kölliker
entities.description: Albert von Kölliker was a Swiss anatomist, physiologist, and histologist.

heading: Births
txt: Adolf Anderssen, German chess player (d. 1879)

entities.title: Adolf Anderssen
entities.description: Karl Ernst Adolf Anderssen was a German chess master. He won the great international tournaments of 1851 and 1862, but lost matches to Paul Morphy in 1858, and to Wilhelm Steinitz in 1866. Accordingly, he is generally regarded as having been the world's leading chess player from 1851 to 1858, and leading active player from 1862 to 1866, although the title of World Chess Champion did not yet exist.

heading: Births
txt: Sophie Adlersparre, Swedish publisher, writer, and women's rights activist (d. 1895)

entities.title: Sophie Adlersparre
entities.description: Carin Sophie Adlersparre née Leijonhufvud was one of the pioneers of the 19th-century women's rights movement in Sweden. She was the founder and editor of the first women's magazine in Scandinavia, Home Review, in 1859-85; co-founder of Friends of Handicraft in 1874-87; founder of the Fredrika Bremer Association (Fredrika-Bremer-förbundet) in 1884; and one of the first two women to be a member of

heading: Births
txt: Frederick VIII, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein (d. 1880)

entities.title: Frederick VIII, Duke of Schleswig-Holstein
entities.description: Duke Frederick VIII was the German pretender to the throne of Schleswig-Holstein from 1863, although in reality Prussia took overlordship and real administrative power.

heading: Births
txt: Sylvester Pennoyer, American lawyer and politician, 8th Governor of Oregon (d. 1902)

entities.title: Sylvester Pennoyer
entities.description: Sylvester Pennoyer was an American educator, attorney, and politician in Oregon. He was born in Groton, New York, attended Harvard Law School, and moved to Oregon at age 25. A Democrat, he served two terms as the eighth Governor of Oregon from 1886 to 1895. He joined the Populist cause in the early 1890s and became the second Populist Party state governor in history. He was noted for his political

entities.title: Governor of Oregon
entities.description: The Governor of Oregon is the head of the executive branch of Oregon's state government and serves as the commander-in-chief of the state's military forces. The title of governor was also applied to the office of Oregon's chief executive during the provisional and U.S. territorial governments.

heading: Births
txt: Maximilian I of Mexico (d. 1867)

entities.title: Maximilian I of Mexico
entities.description: Maximilian I was an Austrian archduke who reigned as the only Emperor of the Second Mexican Empire from 10 April 1864 until his execution on 19 June 1867. A younger brother of Emperor Franz Joseph I of Austria, Maximilian had a distinguished career as commander-in-chief of the Imperial Austrian Navy.

heading: Births
txt: R. G. Bhandarkar, Indian orientalist and scholar (d. 1925)

entities.title: R. G. Bhandarkar
entities.description: Sir Ramakrishna Gopal Bhandarkar was an Indian scholar, orientalist, and social reformer.

heading: Births
txt: Vatroslav Jagić, Croatian philologist and scholar (d. 1923)

entities.title: Vatroslav Jagić
entities.description: Vatroslav Jagić was a Croatian scholar of Slavic studies in the second half of the 19th century.

heading: Births
txt: José María Velasco Gómez, Mexican painter and academic (d. 1912)

entities.title: José María Velasco Gómez
entities.description: José María Tranquilino Francisco de Jesús Velasco Gómez Obregón, generally known as José María Velasco, was a 19th-century Mexican polymath, most famous as a painter who made Mexican geography a symbol of national identity through his paintings. He was both one of the most popular artists of the time and internationally renowned. He received many distinctions such as the gold medal of the Mexican

heading: Births
txt: John Downer, Australian politician, 16th Premier of South Australia (d. 1915)

entities.title: John Downer
entities.description: Sir John William Downer, KCMG, KC was an Australian politician who served two terms as Premier of South Australia, from 1885 to 1887 and again from 1892 to 1893. He later entered federal politics and served as a Senator for South Australia from 1901 to 1903. He was the first of four Australian politicians from the Downer family dynasty.

entities.title: Premier of South Australia
entities.description: The Premier of South Australia is the head of government in the state of South Australia, Australia. The Government of South Australia follows the Westminster system, with a Parliament of South Australia acting as the legislature. The Premier is appointed by the Governor of South Australia, and by modern convention holds office by virtue of his or her ability to command the support of a majority o

heading: Births
txt: George Howard Earle, Jr., American lawyer and businessman (d. 1928)

entities.title: George Howard Earle, Jr.
entities.description: George H. Earle Jr. was a Philadelphia lawyer and "financial diplomat" who was highly sought after to save ailing corporations from financial ruin.

heading: Births
txt: William Irvine, Irish-Australian politician, 21st Premier of Victoria (d. 1943)

entities.title: William Irvine (Australian politician)
entities.description: Sir William Hill Irvine was an Australian politician and judge. He served as Premier of Victoria (1902–1904), Attorney-General of Australia (1913–1914), and Chief Justice of Victoria (1918–1935).

entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

heading: Births
txt: Émile Jaques-Dalcroze, Swiss composer and educator (d. 1950)

entities.title: Émile Jaques-Dalcroze
entities.description: Émile Jaques-Dalcroze was a Swiss composer, musician, and music educator who developed Dalcroze eurhythmics, an approach to learning and experiencing music through movement. Dalcroze eurhythmics influenced Carl Orff's pedagogy, used in music education throughout the United States.

heading: Births
txt: Princess Victoria of the United Kingdom (d. 1935)

entities.title: Princess Victoria of the United Kingdom
entities.description: Princess Victoria of the United Kingdom was the fourth child and second daughter of King Edward VII and Queen Alexandra, and the younger sister of King George V.

heading: Births
txt: Dimitrios Maximos, Greek banker and politician, 140th Prime Minister of Greece (d. 1955)

entities.title: Dimitrios Maximos
entities.description: Dimitrios E. Maximos was a Greek banker and politician. He briefly served as Prime Minister of Greece after World War II.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Greece
entities.description: The prime minister of the Hellenic Republic, colloquially referred to as the prime minister of Greece, is the head of government of the Hellenic Republic and the leader of the Greek Cabinet. The incumbent prime minister is Kyriakos Mitsotakis, who took office on 8 July 2019.

heading: Births
txt: Arnaud Massy, French golfer (d. 1950)

entities.title: Arnaud Massy
entities.description: Arnaud George Watson Massy was one of France's most successful professional golfers, most notable for winning the 1907 Open Championship.

heading: Births
txt: Eino Leino, Finnish poet and journalist (d. 1926)

entities.title: Eino Leino
entities.description: Eino Leino was a Finnish poet and journalist who is considered one of the pioneers of Finnish poetry and a national poet of Finland. His poems combine modern and Finnish folk elements. Much of his work is in the style of the Kalevala and folk songs in general. Nature, love, and despair are frequent themes in Leino's work. He is beloved and widely read in Finland today.

heading: Births
txt: Godfrey Huggins, Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland (d. 1971)

entities.title: Godfrey Huggins
entities.description: Godfrey Martin Huggins, 1st Viscount Malvern, was a Rhodesian politician and physician. He served as the fourth Prime Minister of Southern Rhodesia from 1933 to 1953 and remained in office as the first Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland until October 1956, becoming the longest serving prime minister in British Commonwealth history.

entities.title: Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland
entities.description: The following is a list of the men who served as Prime Minister of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland. The Federation was formed on 1 August 1953 from the former colonies of Southern Rhodesia, Northern Rhodesia and Nyasaland, and was formally dissolved on 31 December 1963.

heading: Births
txt: Harold Stirling Vanderbilt, American businessman and sailor (d. 1970)

entities.title: Harold Stirling Vanderbilt
entities.description: Harold Stirling Vanderbilt CBE was an American railroad executive, a champion yachtsman, an innovator and champion player of contract bridge, and a member of the Vanderbilt family.

heading: Births
txt: Ernst Busch, German field marshal (d. 1945)

entities.title: Ernst Busch (field marshal)
entities.description: Ernst Bernhard Wilhelm Busch was a German Generalfeldmarschall during World War II who commanded the 16th Army and later the massive Army Group Centre.

heading: Births
txt: Marc Bloch, French historian and academic (d. 1944)

entities.title: Marc Bloch
entities.description: Marc Léopold Benjamin Bloch was a French historian. He was a founding member of the Annales School of French social history. Bloch specialised in medieval history and published widely on Medieval France over the course of his career. As an academic, he worked at the University of Strasbourg, the University of Paris, and the University of Montpellier.

heading: Births
txt: Marc Chagall, Belarusian-French painter and poet (d. 1985)

entities.title: Marc Chagall
entities.description: Marc Chagall was a Russian-French artist of Belarusian Jewish origin. An early modernist, he was associated with several major artistic styles and created works in a wide range of artistic formats, including painting, drawings, book illustrations, stained glass, stage sets, ceramics, tapestries and fine art prints.

heading: Births
txt: Annette Kellerman, Australian swimmer and actress (d. 1975)

heading: Births
txt: Dhan Gopal Mukerji, Indian-American author and scholar (d. 1936)

entities.title: Dhan Gopal Mukerji
entities.description: Dhan Gopal Mukerji was the first successful Indian man of letters in the United States and won a Newbery Medal in 1928. He studied at Duff School, and at Duff College, both within the University of Calcutta in India, at the University of Tokyo in Japan and at the University of California, Berkeley and Stanford University in the US.

heading: Births
txt: Will James, American author and illustrator (d. 1942)

entities.title: Will James (artist)
entities.description: Will James was a French Canadian artist and writer of the American West. He is known for writing Smoky the Cowhorse, for which he won the 1927 Newbery Medal, and numerous "cowboy" stories for adults and children. His artwork, which predominantly involved cowboy and rodeo scenes, followed "in the tradition of Charles Russell", and much of it was used to illustrate his books. In 1992, he was inducte

heading: Births
txt: Richard Krautheimer, German-American historian and scholar (d. 1994)

entities.title: Richard Krautheimer
entities.description: Richard Krautheimer was a 20th-century art historian, architectural historian, Baroque scholar, and Byzantinist.

heading: Births
txt: Hanns Eisler, German-Austrian soldier and composer (d. 1962)

entities.title: Hanns Eisler
entities.description: Hanns Eisler was an Austrian composer. He is best known for composing the national anthem of East Germany, for his long artistic association with Bertolt Brecht, and for the scores he wrote for films. The Hochschule für Musik "Hanns Eisler" is named after him.

heading: Births
txt: Susannah Mushatt Jones, American supercentarian (d. 2016)

entities.title: Susannah Mushatt Jones
entities.description: Susannah Mushatt Jones was an American supercentenarian who was, at the age of 116 years and 311 days, the world's oldest living person and the last living American born in the 19th century. She received tributes from the United States House of Representatives and from the Alabama House of Representatives "for a remarkable lifetime of exceptional achievement lived during three centuries".

entities.title: Supercentarian
entities.description: A supercentenarian is someone who has reached the age of 110. This age is achieved by about one in 1,000 centenarians. Anderson et al. concluded that supercentenarians live a life typically free of major age-related diseases until shortly before maximum human lifespan is reached.

heading: Births
txt: Frederica Sagor Maas, American author and screenwriter (d. 2012)

entities.title: Frederica Sagor Maas
entities.description:
Frederica Alexandrina Sagor Maas was an American dramatist and playwright, screenwriter, memoirist, and author, 
the youngest daughter of Jewish immigrants from Russia. As an essayist, Maas was best known for a detailed, tell-all memoir of her time spent in early Hollywood. A supercentenarian, she was one of the oldest surviving entertainers from the silent film era.

heading: Births
txt: Elfriede Wever, German Olympic runner (d. 1941)

heading: Births
txt: Hugo Theorell, Swedish biochemist and academic, Nobel Prize laureate (d. 1982)

entities.title: Hugo Theorell
entities.description: Axel Hugo Theodor Theorell was a Swedish scientist and Nobel Prize laureate in medicine.

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine is awarded yearly by the Nobel Assembly at the Karolinska Institutet for outstanding discoveries in physiology or medicine.

heading: Births
txt: Robert Whitney, American conductor and composer (d. 1986)

entities.title: Robert Whitney (conductor)
entities.description: Robert Sutton Whitney was an American conductor and composer. He was a student of Leo Sowerby.

heading: Births
txt: Erik Wickberg, Swedish 9th General of The Salvation Army (d. 1996)

entities.title: General of The Salvation Army
entities.description: General is the title of the international leader and Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the Salvation Army, a Christian denomination with extensive charitable social services that gives quasi-military rank to its ministers. The General is elected by the High Council of The Salvation Army and serves a term of five years, which may be extended to seven years. Brian Peddle, the current general, assumed

heading: Births
txt: Juan O'Gorman, Mexican painter and architect (d. 1982)

entities.title: Juan O'Gorman
entities.description: Juan O'Gorman was a Mexican painter and architect.

heading: Births
txt: Frida Kahlo, Mexican painter and educator (d. 1954)

entities.title: Frida Kahlo
entities.description: Magdalena Carmen Frida Kahlo y Calderón was a Mexican painter known for her many portraits, self-portraits, and works inspired by the nature and artifacts of Mexico. entities.title: Premier of Victoria
entities.description: The Premier of Victoria is the head of government in the Australian state of Victoria. The Premier is appointed by the governor of Victoria, and is the leader of the political party able to secure a majority in the Victorian Legislative Assembly.

entities.description: Curtis James Jackson III, known professionally as 50 Cent, is an American rapper, songwriter, television producer, actor, and entrepreneur. Known for his impact in the hip hop industry, he has been described as a "master of the nuanced art of lyrical brevity".

Cester is also a founder of the Australian supergroup The Wrights. Jet's track "Are You Gonna Be My Girl", has won APRA Awards for 'Most Performed Australian Work Overseas' in 2006 and 2007.

He played college football for the University of California, Berkeley, and was drafted in the first round of the 2003 NFL Draft by the Oakland Raiders. heading: Births

heading: Births
txt: Brandon Jacobs, American football player

entities.title: Brandon Jacobs
entities.description: Brandon Christopher Jacobs is a former American football running back, who spent the majority of his career with the New York Giants of the National Football League (NFL). He played college football at Coffeyville, Auburn, and Southern Illinois. He was drafted by the Giants in the fourth round of the 2005 NFL Draft, and won two Super Bowl rings with the team, both against the New England Patriots.

entities.description: Gregory Edward Smith is a Canadian actor, writer, and director. Smith has appeared in several Hollywood films, and is known for his roles as Alan Abernathy in Small Soldiers, Ephram Brown on the television series Everwood, and as Dov Epstein on the police drama series Rookie Blue.

heading: Births
txt: Zhang Hao, Chinese figure skater

entities.title: Zhang Hao (figure skater)
entities.description: Zhang Hao is a Chinese retired pair skater. With current partner Yu Xiaoyu, he is the 2016–17 Grand Prix Final silver medalist, 2017 Asian Winter Games champion and 2018 Chinese national champion. With former partner Peng Cheng, he is the 2015 Four Continents silver medalist. With former partner Zhang Dan, he is the 2006 Olympic silver medalist, a four-time World medalist, and a two-time Four Cont

heading: Births
txt: Ranveer Singh, Indian film actor

entities.title: Ranveer Singh
entities.description: Ranveer Singh Bhavnani is an Indian actor who is known for his work in Hindi films. The recipient of several awards, including four Filmfare Awards, he is among the highest-paid Indian actors and has been featured in Forbes India's Celebrity 100 list since 2012.

heading: Births
txt: David Karp, American businessman, founded Tumblr

entities.title: David Karp
entities.description: David Karp is an American web developer and entrepreneur. He is the founder and former CEO of the short-form blogging platform Tumblr.

entities.title: Tumblr
entities.description: Tumblr is an American microblogging and social networking website founded by David Karp in 2007 and currently owned by Automattic. The service allows users to post multimedia and other content to a short-form blog. Users can follow other users' blogs. Bloggers can also make their blogs private. For bloggers many of the website's features are accessed from a "dashboard" interface.

entities.description: Magaye Serigne Falilou Gueye is a professional footballer who plays as a forward. He is a former French youth and under-21 international, but in 2012 he accepted a call up from Senegal for the Olympic games tournament, eligible due to his Senegalese parentage. Gueye started his professional career with RC Strasbourg in France, before moving to Everton in 2010. He made 24 appearances for Everton in

heading: Births
txt: Manny Machado, Dominican-American baseball player

entities.title: Manny Machado
entities.description: Manuel Arturo Machado is a Dominican-American professional baseball third baseman and shortstop for the San Diego Padres of Major League Baseball (MLB). Very highly recruited from an early age, he was raised in Miami, where he attended Brito High School and was drafted by the Baltimore Orioles with the third overall pick in the 2010 MLB draft. He bats and throws right-handed.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cleombrotus I, Spartan king

entities.title: Cleombrotus I
entities.description: Cleombrotus I was a Spartan king of the Agiad line, reigning from 380 BC until 371 BC. Little is known of Cleombrotus' early life. Son of Pausanias, he became king of Sparta after the death of his brother Agesipolis I in 380 BC, and led the allied Spartan-Peloponnesian army against the Thebans under Epaminondas in the Battle of Leuctra. His death and the utter defeat of his army led to the end of

heading: Deaths
txt: Goar of Aquitaine, French bishop

entities.title: Goar of Aquitaine
entities.description: Saint Goar of Aquitaine was a priest and hermit of the seventh century. He was offered the position of Bishop of Trier, but prayed to be excused from the position. Goar is noted for his piety and is revered as a miracle-worker. He is a patron saint of innkeepers, potters, and vine growers.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wang Chongrong, Chinese warlord

entities.title: Wang Chongrong
entities.description: Wang Chongrong (王重榮), formally the Prince of Langye (瑯琊王), was a warlord of the late Chinese dynasty Tang Dynasty who controlled Hezhong Circuit. He was instrumental in Tang's eventual defeat of the agrarian rebel Huang Chao, but at times had an adversarial relationship with the court of Emperor Xizong and the powerful eunuch Tian Lingzi.

heading: Deaths
txt: William I, duke of Aquitaine (b. 875)

entities.title: William I, Duke of Aquitaine
entities.description: William I, called the Pious, was the Count of Auvergne from 886 and Duke of Aquitaine from 893, succeeding the Poitevin ruler Ebalus Manser. He made numerous monastic foundations, most important among them the foundation of Cluny Abbey on 11 September 910.

heading: Deaths
txt: Genshin, Japanese scholar (b. 942)

entities.title: Genshin
entities.description: Genshin , also known as Eshin Sōzu (恵心僧都), was the most influential of a number of scholar-monks of the Buddhist Tendai sect active during the tenth and eleventh centuries in Japan. Genshin, who was trained in both esoteric and exoteric teachings, wrote a number of treatises pertaining to the increasingly popular Pure Land Buddhism from a Tendai viewpoint, but his magnum opus, the Ōjōyōshū  had co

heading: Deaths
txt: Godelieve, Flemish saint (b. 1049)

entities.title: Godelieve
entities.description: Saint Godelieve is a Flemish saint. She was martyred by the servants of her angry husband because she preferred to become a nun rather than marry.

heading: Deaths
txt: Henry II, king of England (b. 1133)

entities.title: Henry II of England
entities.description: Henry II, also known as Henry Curtmantle, Henry FitzEmpress or Henry Plantagenet, was King of England from 1154 until his death in 1189. He was the first king of the House of Plantagenet. King Louis VII of France made him Duke of Normandy in 1150. Henry became Count of Anjou and Maine upon the death of his father, Count Geoffrey V, in 1151. His marriage in 1152 to Eleanor of Aquitaine, whose marri

heading: Deaths
txt: Odo III, duke of Burgundy (b. 1166)

entities.title: Odo III, Duke of Burgundy
entities.description: Eudes III, commonly known in English as Odo III, was duke of Burgundy between 1192 and 1218. Odo was the eldest son of duke Hugh III and his first wife Alice, daughter of Matthias I, Duke of Lorraine.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alexander II, king of Scotland (b. 1198)

entities.title: Alexander II of Scotland
entities.description: Alexander II was King of Scotland from 1214 until his death. He concluded the Treaty of York (1237) which defined the boundary between England and Scotland, virtually unchanged today.

heading: Deaths
txt: Jan Hus, Czech priest, philosopher, and reformer (b. 1369)

entities.title: Jan Hus
entities.description: Jan Hus, sometimes anglicized as John Hus or John Huss, and referred to in historical texts as Iohannes Hus or Johannes Huss, was a Czech theologian and philosopher who became a Church reformer and the inspiration of Hussitism, a key predecessor to Protestantism and a seminal figure in the Bohemian Reformation. After John Wycliffe, the theorist of ecclesiastical reform, Hus is considered the secon

heading: Deaths
txt: Regiomontanus, German mathematician and astrologer (b. 1436)

entities.title: Regiomontanus
entities.description: Johannes Müller von Königsberg, better known as Regiomontanus, was a mathematician, astrologer and astronomer of the German Renaissance, active in Vienna, Buda and Nuremberg. His contributions were instrumental in the development of Copernican heliocentrism in the decades following his death.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antonio Squarcialupi, Italian composer (b. 1416)

entities.title: Antonio Squarcialupi
entities.description: Antonio Squarcialupi was an Italian organist and composer. He was the most famous organist in Italy in the mid-15th century.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ludovico Ariosto, Italian poet and playwright (b. 1474)

entities.title: Ludovico Ariosto
entities.description: Ludovico Ariosto was an Italian poet. He is best known as the author of the romance epic Orlando Furioso (1516). The poem, a continuation of Matteo Maria Boiardo's Orlando Innamorato, describes the adventures of Charlemagne, Orlando, and the Franks as they battle against the Saracens with diversions into many sideplots. The poem is transformed into a satire of the chivalric tradition. Ariosto comp

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas More, English lawyer and politician, Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster (b. 1478)

entities.title: Thomas More
entities.description: Sir Thomas More, venerated in the Catholic Church as Saint Thomas More, was an English lawyer, judge, social philosopher, author, statesman, and noted Renaissance humanist. He also served Henry VIII as Lord High Chancellor of England from October 1529 to May 1532. He wrote Utopia, published in 1516, which describes the political system of an imaginary island state.

entities.title: Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster
entities.description: The Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster is a ministerial office in the Government of the United Kingdom that includes as part of its duties the administration of the estates and rents of the Duchy of Lancaster.

heading: Deaths
txt: Edward VI, king of England and Ireland (b. 1537)

entities.title: Edward VI of England
entities.description: Edward VI was the King of England and Ireland from 28 January 1547 until his death in 1553. He was crowned on 20 February at the age of nine. Edward was the son of Henry VIII and Jane Seymour, and England's first monarch to be raised as a Protestant. During his reign, the realm was governed by a regency council because he never reached maturity. The council was first led by his uncle Edward Seymou

heading: Deaths
txt: Edmund Grindal, English archbishop (b. 1519)

entities.title: Edmund Grindal
entities.description: Edmund Grindal was a prelate of the Church of England who, during the reign of Elizabeth I, was successively Bishop of London, Archbishop of York, and Archbishop of Canterbury. Though born far from the centres of political and religious power, he had risen rapidly in the church during the reign of Edward VI, culminating in his nomination as Bishop of London; the death of the King prevented his tak

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Aufield, English priest and martyr (b. 1552)

entities.title: Thomas Aufield
entities.description: Thomas Aufield, also called Thomas Alfield, was an English Roman Catholic martyr.

heading: Deaths
txt: Man Singh I, Rajput Raja of Amer (b. 1550)

entities.title: Man Singh I
entities.description: Raja Man Singh was the Kachwaha Raja of Amer, a state later known as Jaipur in Rajputana. He was a trusted general of the Mughal emperor Akbar, who included him among the Navaratnas, or the nine (nava) gems (ratna) of the royal court of Akbar.

heading: Deaths
txt: Peter Gunning, English bishop (b. 1614)

entities.title: Peter Gunning
entities.description: Peter Gunning was an English Royalist church leader, Bishop of Chichester and Bishop of Ely.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Howe, 3rd Viscount Howe, English general and politician (b. 1725)

entities.title: George Howe, 3rd Viscount Howe
entities.description: George Augustus Howe, 3rd Viscount Howe was a career officer and a Brigadier General in the British Army. He was described by James Wolfe as "the best officer in the British Army". He was killed in the French and Indian War in a skirmish at Fort Ticonderoga the day before the Battle of Carillon, an ultimately disastrous attempt by the British to capture French-controlled Fort Carillon.

heading: Deaths
txt: Conrad Beissel, German-American religious leader (b. 1690)

entities.title: Conrad Beissel
entities.description: Georg Conrad Beissel was a German-born religious leader who in 1732 founded the Ephrata Community in the Province of Pennsylvania.

heading: Deaths
txt: Daniel Morgan, American general and politician (b. 1736)

entities.title: Daniel Morgan
entities.description: Daniel Morgan was an American pioneer, soldier, and politician from Virginia. One of the most respected battlefield tacticians of the American Revolutionary War of 1775–1783, he later commanded troops during the suppression of the Whiskey Rebellion of 1791–1794.

heading: Deaths
txt: Antoine Charles Louis de Lasalle, French general (b. 1775)

entities.title: Antoine Charles Louis de Lasalle
entities.description: Antoine-Charles-Louis, Comte de Lasalle was a French cavalry general during the Revolutionary and Napoleonic Wars, often called "The Hussar General". He first gained fame for his role in the Capitulation of Stettin. Over the course of his short career, he became known as a daring adventurer and was credited with many exploits. Eventually, he fought on every front and was killed at the Battle of Wa

heading: Deaths
txt: Granville Sharp, English activist (b. 1735)

entities.title: Granville Sharp
entities.description: Granville Sharp was one of the first British campaigners for the abolition of the slave trade. He also involved himself in trying to correct other social injustices. Sharp formulated the plan to settle black people in Sierra Leone, and founded the St George's Bay Company, a forerunner of the Sierra Leone Company. His efforts led to both the founding of the Province of Freedom, and later on Freetow

heading: Deaths
txt: Samuel Whitbread, English politician (b. 1764)

entities.title: Samuel Whitbread (1764–1815)
entities.description: Samuel Whitbread was a British politician.

heading: Deaths
txt: John Marshall, American captain and politician, 4th United States Secretary of State (b. 1755)

entities.title: John Marshall
entities.description: John Marshall was an American politician and lawyer who served as the fourth Chief Justice of the United States from 1801 to 1835. Marshall remains the longest-serving chief justice and fourth-longest serving justice in Supreme Court history, and he is widely regarded as one of the most influential justices to ever sit on the Supreme Court. Prior to joining the Supreme Court, Marshall served as th

entities.title: United States Secretary of State
entities.description: The United States secretary of state implements foreign policy for the U.S. government as the head of the U.S. Department of State. Created in 1789, the Cabinet position is analogous to a foreign minister in other countries.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georg Ohm, German physicist and mathematician (b. 1789)

entities.title: Georg Ohm
entities.description: Georg Simon Ohm was a German physicist and mathematician. As a school teacher, Ohm began his research with the new electrochemical cell, invented by Italian scientist Alessandro Volta. Using equipment of his own creation, Ohm found that there is a direct proportionality between the potential difference (voltage) applied across a conductor and the resultant electric current. This relationship is kn

heading: Deaths
txt: Harada Sanosuke, Japanese captain (b. 1840)

entities.title: Harada Sanosuke
entities.description: Harada Sanosuke  was a Japanese warrior (samurai) who lived in the late Edo period. He was the 10th unit captain of the Shinsengumi, and died during the Boshin War.

heading: Deaths
txt: Guy de Maupassant, French short story writer, novelist, and poet (b. 1850)

entities.title: Guy de Maupassant
entities.description: Henri René Albert Guy de Maupassant was a 19th-century French author, remembered as a master of the short story form, and as a representative of the Naturalist school, who depicted human lives and destinies and social forces in disillusioned and often pessimistic terms.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chlodwig Carl Viktor, German prince and chancellor (b. 1819)

entities.title: Chlodwig, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst
entities.description: Chlodwig Carl Viktor, Prince of Hohenlohe-Schillingsfürst, Prince of Ratibor and Corvey, usually referred to as the Prince of Hohenlohe, was a German statesman, who served as Chancellor of Germany and Prime Minister of Prussia from 1894 to 1900. Prior to his appointment as Chancellor, he had served in a number of other positions, including as Prime Minister of Bavaria (1866–1870), German Ambassado

heading: Deaths
txt: Maria Goretti, Italian martyr and saint (b. 1890)

entities.title: Maria Goretti
entities.description: Maria Teresa Goretti is an Italian virgin-martyr of the Catholic Church, and one of the youngest saints to be canonized. She was born to a farming family. Her father died when she was nine, and they had to share a house with another family, the Serenellis. Maria took over household duties while her mother, brothers, and sister worked in the fields.

heading: Deaths
txt: Abai Qunanbaiuly, Kazakh poet and philosopher (b. 1845)

entities.title: Abai Qunanbaiuly
entities.description: Ibrahim (Abai) Qunanbaiuly was a Kazakh poet, composer and Hanafi Maturidi theologian philosopher. He was also a cultural reformer toward European and Russian cultures on the basis of enlightened Islam. His name is also transliterated as Abay Kunanbayev ; among Kazakhs he is known as Abai.

heading: Deaths
txt: August Johann Gottfried Bielenstein, German linguist and theologian (b. 1826)

entities.title: August Johann Gottfried Bielenstein
entities.description: August Johann Gottfried Bielenstein was a Baltic German linguist, folklorist, ethnographer, and theologian.

heading: Deaths
txt: Georges Legagneux, French aviator (b. 1882)

entities.title: Georges Legagneux
entities.description: Georges Théophile Legagneux was a French pioneer aviator, the first person to fly higher than 10,000 feet and the first to fly a plane in Austria, Sweden and Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Odilon Redon, French painter and illustrator (b. 1840)

entities.title: Odilon Redon
entities.description: Odilon Redon was a French symbolist painter, printmaker, draughtsman and pastellist.

heading: Deaths
txt: Wilhelm von Mirbach, German diplomat (b. 1871)

entities.title: Wilhelm von Mirbach
entities.description: Wilhelm Maria Theodor Ernst Richard Graf von Mirbach-Harff was a German diplomat.

heading: Deaths
txt: Maria Teresia Ledóchowska, Polish-Austrian nun and missionary (b. 1863)

entities.title: Maria Teresia Ledóchowska
entities.description: Mary Theresa Ledóchowska, was a Polish Roman Catholic Religious Sister and missionary, who founded the Missionary Sisters of St. Peter Claver, dedicated to service in Africa. She has been beatified by the Catholic Church.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kenneth Grahame, Scottish-English author (b. 1859)

entities.title: Kenneth Grahame
entities.description: Kenneth Grahame was a British writer born in Edinburgh, Scotland. He is most famous for The Wind in the Willows (1908), one of the classics of children's literature. He also wrote The Reluctant Dragon. Both books were later adapted for stage and film, of which A. A. Milne's Toad of Toad Hall, based on part of The Wind in the Willows, was the first. Other adaptations include the Disney films The Ad

heading: Deaths
txt: Nestor Makhno, Ukrainian commander (b. 1888)

entities.title: Nestor Makhno
entities.description: Nestor Ivanovych Makhno, commonly known as Bat'ko Makhno, was a Ukrainian anarchist revolutionary and the commander of an independent anarchist army in Ukraine from 1917–21.

heading: Deaths
txt: Horace Pippin, American painter (b. 1888)

entities.title: Horace Pippin
entities.description: Horace Pippin was a self-taught American artist who painted a range of themes, including scenes inspired by his service in World War I, landscapes, portraits, and biblical subjects. Some of his best-known works address the U.S.'s history of slavery and racial segregation. He was the first Black artist to be the subject of a monograph, Selden Rodman's Horace Pippin, A Negro Painter in America (1947

heading: Deaths
txt: Adolfo Müller-Ury, Swiss-American painter (b. 1862)

entities.title: Adolfo Müller-Ury
entities.description: Adolfo Müller-Ury, KSG was a Swiss-born American portrait painter and impressionistic painter of roses and still life.

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis-Alexandre Taschereau, Canadian lawyer and politician, 14th Premier of Quebec (b. 1867)

entities.title: Louis-Alexandre Taschereau
entities.description: Louis-Alexandre Taschereau was the 14th Premier of the Canadian province of Quebec from 1920 to 1936. He was elected four times, the first in 1900, in the riding of Montmorency. He was also a member of the Parti libéral du Québec.

entities.title: Premier of Quebec
entities.description: The Premier of Quebec is the head of government of the Canadian province of Quebec. The current Premier of Quebec is François Legault of the Coalition Avenir Québec, sworn in on October 18, 2018 following the 2018 election.

heading: Deaths
txt: George Grosz, German painter and illustrator (b. 1893)

entities.title: George Grosz
entities.description: George Grosz was a German artist known especially for his caricatural drawings and paintings of Berlin life in the 1920s. He was a prominent member of the Berlin Dada and New Objectivity groups during the Weimar Republic. He immigrated to the United States in 1933, and became a naturalized citizen in 1938. Abandoning the style and subject matter of his earlier work, he exhibited regularly and taug

heading: Deaths
txt: Aneurin Bevan, Welsh-English politician, Secretary of State for Health (b. 1897)

entities.title: Aneurin Bevan
entities.description: Aneurin Bevan PC, often known as Nye Bevan, was a Welsh Labour Party politician. Born into a working-class family in South Wales, he was the son of a coal miner. He left school at 13 and worked as a miner during his teens where he became involved in local union politics. He was named head of his Miners' Lodge when aged 19, where he frequently railed against management. He joined the Labour Party a

entities.title: Secretary of State for Health
entities.description: The Secretary of State for Health and Social Care, also referred to as the Health Secretary, is a secretary of state position within the Government of the United Kingdom, and leader of the Department of Health and Social Care (DHSC). The postholder has responsibility for all health and social care matters in England, including England's National Health Service (NHS). Alongside the Chief Medical Of

heading: Deaths
txt: Scott LaFaro, American bassist (b. 1936)

entities.title: Scott LaFaro
entities.description: Rocco Scott LaFaro was an American jazz double bassist known for his work with the Bill Evans Trio. Despite his short career, he was ranked #16 on Bass Player magazine's top 100 bass players of all time.

heading: Deaths
txt: Woodall Rodgers, American lawyer and politician, Mayor of Dallas (b. 1890)

entities.title: Mayor of Dallas
entities.description: The Mayor of the City of Dallas is the head of the Dallas City Council. The current mayor is Eric Johnson, who has served one term since 2019 and is the 62nd mayor to serve the position. Dallas operates under a weak-mayor system, and a board-appointed city manager operates as the chief executive of the city.

heading: Deaths
txt: Paul Boffa, Maltese soldier and politician, 5th Prime Minister of Malta (b. 1890)

entities.title: Paul Boffa
entities.description: Sir Paul Boffa, OBE was a Maltese prime minister (1947–50) who took office after self-rule was reinstated by the British colonial authority following the end of World War II.

entities.title: Prime Minister of Malta
entities.description: The Prime Minister of Malta is the head of government, which is the highest official of Malta.

heading: Deaths
txt: William Faulkner, American novelist and short story writer, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1897)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Joseph August, archduke of Austria (b. 1872)

heading: Deaths
txt: George, duke of Mecklenburg (b. 1899)

entities.title: George, Duke of Mecklenburg
entities.description: George, Duke of Mecklenburg was the head of the House of Mecklenburg-Strelitz from 1934 until his death. Through his father, he was a descendant of Emperor Paul I of Russia.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claude V. Ricketts, American admiral (b. 1906)

entities.title: Claude V. Ricketts
entities.description: Claude Vernon Ricketts was a four-star admiral in the United States Navy, who served as the Vice Chief of Naval Operations from 1961 to 1964.

heading: Deaths
txt: Sad Sam Jones, American baseball player and manager (b. 1892)

entities.title: Sad Sam Jones
entities.description: Samuel Pond "Sad Sam" Jones was an American Major League Baseball pitcher with the Cleveland Indians, Boston Red Sox, New York Yankees, St. Louis Browns, Washington Senators and the Chicago White Sox between 1914 and 1935. Jones batted and threw right-handed. His sharp breaking curveball also earned him the nickname "Horsewhips Sam".

heading: Deaths
txt: Hilda Taba, Estonian architect and educator (b. 1902)

entities.title: Hilda Taba
entities.description: Hilda Taba was an architect, a curriculum theorist, a curriculum reformer, and a teacher educator. Taba was born in the small village of Kooraste, Estonia. Her mother's name was Liisa Leht, and her father was a schoolmaster whose name was Robert Taba. Hilda Taba began her education at the Kanepi Parish School. She then attended the Võru’s Girls’ Grammar School and earned her undergraduate degree i

heading: Deaths
txt: Louis Armstrong, American singer and trumpet player (b. 1901)

entities.title: Louis Armstrong
entities.description: Louis Daniel Armstrong, nicknamed "Satchmo", "Satch", and "Pops", was an American trumpeter and vocalist who was among the most influential figures in jazz. His career spanned five decades and different eras in the history of jazz.

heading: Deaths
txt: Otto Klemperer, German-American conductor and composer (b. 1885)

entities.title: Otto Klemperer
entities.description: Otto Nossan Klemperer was a German-born orchestral conductor and composer, described as "the last of the few really great conductors of his generation."

heading: Deaths
txt: Reşat Ekrem Koçu, Turkish historian, scholar, and poet (b. 1905)

entities.title: Reşat Ekrem Koçu
entities.description: Reşat Ekrem Koçu was a Turkish writer and historian. His best known work is his unfinished Istanbul Encyclopedia, which recounts many tales of Istanbul from Ottoman times. Koçu and his colorful depictions of Ottoman Istanbul are celebrated in Orhan Pamuk's book Istanbul: Memories and the City.

heading: Deaths
txt: Zhu De, Chinese general and politician, Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress (b. 1886)

entities.title: Zhu De
entities.description: Zhu De was a Chinese general, military strategist, politician, revolutionary of the Chinese Communist Party. Born poor in 1886 in Sichuan, he was adopted by a wealthy uncle at age nine. His wealthy uncle provided him a superior early education that led to his admission into a military academy. After the academy, he joined a rebel army and soon became a warlord. It was after this period that he ado

entities.title: Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress
entities.description: The Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, officially styled the Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China, is the presiding officer of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress of the People's Republic of China, which is considered China's top legislative body. The current Chairman is Li Zha

heading: Deaths
txt: Fritz Lenz, German geneticist and physician (b. 1887)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ödön Pártos, Hungarian-Israeli viola player and composer (b. 1907)

entities.title: Ödön Pártos
entities.description: Ödön Pártos [alternate transcription in English: Oedoen Partos, Hungarian: Pártos Ödön, Hebrew: עֵדֶן פרטוש‎ ] was a Hungarian-Israeli violist and composer. A recipient of the Israel Prize, he taught and served as director of the Rubin Academy of Music, now known as the Buchmann-Mehta School of Music in Tel Aviv.

heading: Deaths
txt: Babe Paley, American socialite and fashion style icon (b. 1915)

entities.title: Babe Paley
entities.description: Barbara "Babe" Cushing Mortimer Paley was an American socialite and style icon, whose second husband was the founder of CBS, William S. Paley. She was known by the nickname "Babe" for most of her life. She was named to the International Best Dressed List Hall of Fame in 1958.

heading: Deaths
txt: Van McCoy, American singer-songwriter and producer (b. 1940)

entities.title: Van McCoy
entities.description: Van Allen Clinton McCoy was an American musician, record producer, arranger, songwriter, singer and orchestra conductor. He is known best for his 1975 internationally successful song "The Hustle". He has approximately 700 song copyrights to his credit, and is also noted for producing songs for such recording artists as Gladys Knight & the Pips, The Stylistics, Aretha Franklin, Brenda & the Tabulat

heading: Deaths
txt: Jagjivan Ram, Indian lawyer and politician, 4th Deputy Prime Minister of India (b. 1908)

entities.title: Jagjivan Ram
entities.description: Jagjivan Ram, known popularly as Babuji, was an Indian independence activist and politician from Bihar. He was instrumental in the foundation of the All India Depressed Classes League, an organisation dedicated to attaining equality for untouchables, in 1935 and was elected to Bihar Legislative Assembly in 1937, after which he organised the rural labour movement.

entities.title: Deputy Prime Minister of India
entities.description: The Deputy Prime Minister of India is the deputy to the Prime Minister of India, who is head of the government of India. The deputy prime minister is the second highest ranking member of the Union Council of Ministers. A deputy prime minister usually also holds a cabinet portfolio such as the home minister, defence minister or finance minister. In the parliamentary system of government, the prime

heading: Deaths
txt: János Kádár, Hungarian mechanic and politician, Hungarian Minister of the Interior (b. 1912)

entities.title: János Kádár
entities.description: János József Kádár was a Hungarian communist leader and the General Secretary of the Hungarian Socialist Workers' Party, His 32-year term went through two stages. First (1956–1962), he was a dictator who imposed an iron-fisted rule of Communist Party terror on Hungary. In stage two (1962–1988) he became a champion of liberal communism who focused on economic reform and softening of police state me

entities.title: Ministry of Interior (Hungary)
entities.description: The Ministry of Interior of Hungary is a part of the Hungarian state organisation. Its head, the Minister of Interior, is a member of the Hungarian cabinet. The ministry was established in 1848.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mudashiru Lawal, Nigerian footballer (b. 1954)

entities.title: Mudashiru Lawal
entities.description: Mudashiru Babatunde "Muda" Lawal was a Nigerian footballer who played as a midfielder for both club and country.

heading: Deaths
txt: Marsha P. Johnson, American drag queen performer and activist (b. 1945)

entities.title: Marsha P. Johnson
entities.description: Marsha P. Johnson, born and also known as Malcolm Michaels Jr., was an American gay liberation activist and self-identified drag queen. Known as an outspoken advocate for gay rights, Johnson was one of the prominent figures in the Stonewall uprising of 1969. Johnson was a founding member of the Gay Liberation Front and co-founded the radical activist group Street Transvestite Action Revolutionarie

entities.title: Drag queen
entities.description: A drag queen is a person, usually male, who uses drag clothing and makeup to imitate and often exaggerate female gender signifiers and gender roles for entertainment purposes. Historically, most drag queens have been men dressing as women. In modern times, drag queens are associated with gay men and gay culture, but they can be of any gender and sexual identity.

heading: Deaths
txt: Ahmet Haxhiu, Kosovan activist (b. 1932)

entities.title: Ahmet Haxhiu
entities.description: Ahmet Haxhiu was a Kosovo Albanian political activist and one of the main gunrunners for Kosovo Liberation Army in the early 1990s. He was one of the leading figures of the Revolutionary Movement for Albanian Unification, which aimed at uniting various illegal groups who fought against the government of FR Yugoslavia. Haxhiu later joined People's Movement of Kosovo and was considered the right han

heading: Deaths
txt: Aziz Nesin, Turkish author and poet (b. 1915)

entities.title: Aziz Nesin
entities.description: Aziz Nesin was a Turkish writer, humorist and the author of more than 100 books. Born in a time when Turks did not have official surnames, he had to adopt one after the Surname Law of 1934 was passed. Although his family carried the epithet "Topalosmanoğlu", after an ancestor named "Topal Osman", he chose the surname "Nesin". In Turkish, Nesin? means, What are you?.

heading: Deaths
txt: Chetan Anand, Indian director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1921)

entities.title: Chetan Anand (director)
entities.description: Chetan Anand was a Hindi film producer, screenwriter and director from India, whose debut film, Neecha Nagar, was awarded the Grand Prix Prize at the first ever Cannes Film Festival in 1946. Later he co-founded Navketan Films with his younger brother Dev Anand in 1949.

heading: Deaths
txt: Roy Rogers, American cowboy, actor, and singer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Roy Rogers
entities.description: Roy Rogers was an American singer, actor, and television host. Following early work under his given name, first as co-founder of the Sons of the Pioneers and then acting, the rebranded Rogers then became one of the most popular Western stars of his era. Known as the "King of the Cowboys", he appeared in over 100 films and numerous radio and television episodes of The Roy Rogers Show. In many of hi

heading: Deaths
txt: Joaquín Rodrigo, Spanish pianist and composer (b. 1901)

entities.title: Joaquín Rodrigo
entities.description: Joaquín Rodrigo Vidre, 1st Marquess of the Gardens of Aranjuez, was a Spanish composer and a virtuoso pianist. He is best known for composing the Concierto de Aranjuez, a cornerstone of the classical guitar repertoire.

heading: Deaths
txt: Władysław Szpilman, Polish pianist and composer (b. 1911)

entities.title: Władysław Szpilman
entities.description: Władysław Szpilman was a Polish pianist and classical composer of Jewish descent. Szpilman is widely known as the central figure in the 2002 Roman Polanski film The Pianist, which was based on Szpilman's autobiographical account of how he survived the German occupation of Warsaw and the Holocaust.

heading: Deaths
txt: Dhirubhai Ambani, Indian businessman, founded Reliance Industries (b. 1932)

entities.title: Dhirubhai Ambani
entities.description: Dhirajlal Hirachand Ambani, popularly known as Dhirubhai Ambani was a successful Indian business tycoon who founded Reliance Industries. Ambani took Reliance public in 1977 and was worth $25.6 billion upon his death. In 2016, he was honoured posthumously with the Padma Vibhushan, India's second-highest civilian honour for his contributions to trade and industry.

entities.title: Reliance Industries
entities.description: Reliance Industries Limited (RIL) is an Indian multinational conglomerate company headquartered in Mumbai, India. Reliance owns businesses across India engaged in energy, petrochemicals, textiles, natural resources, retail, and telecommunications. Reliance is one of the most profitable companies in India, the largest publicly traded company in India by market capitalisation, and the largest compan

heading: Deaths
txt: John Frankenheimer, American director, producer, and screenwriter (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Buddy Ebsen, American actor, singer, and dancer (b. 1908)

entities.title: Buddy Ebsen
entities.description: Buddy Ebsen, was an American actor, comedian, and dancer, whose career spanned seven decades. His most famous role was as Jed Clampett in the CBS television sitcom The Beverly Hillbillies (1962–1971); afterwards he starred as the title character in the television detective drama Barnaby Jones (1973–1980).

heading: Deaths
txt: Çelik Gülersoy, Turkish lawyer, historical preservationist, writer and poet (b. 1930)

heading: Deaths
txt: Thomas Klestil, Austrian politician, 10th President of Austria (b. 1932)

entities.title: Thomas Klestil
entities.description: Thomas Klestil was an Austrian diplomat and politician. He served as President of Austria from 1992 to his death in 2004. He was elected in 1992 and re-elected into office in 1998.

entities.title: List of Federal Presidents of Austria
entities.description: The president of Austria is the head of state of the Austrian Republic. Though theoretically entrusted with great power by the Constitution, in practice the president is largely a ceremonial and symbolic figurehead.

heading: Deaths
txt: Syreeta Wright, American singer-songwriter (b. 1946)

heading: Deaths
txt: Ed McBain, American author and screenwriter (b. 1926)

entities.title: Ed McBain
entities.description: Ed McBain was an American author and screenwriter. Born Salvatore Albert Lombino, he legally adopted the name Evan Hunter in 1952. While successful and well known as Evan Hunter, he was even better known as Ed McBain, a name he used for most of his crime fiction, beginning in 1956. He also used the pen names John Abbott, Curt Cannon, Hunt Collins, Ezra Hannon, and Richard Marsten, amongst others.

heading: Deaths
txt: Claude Simon, Malagasy-French novelist and critic, Nobel Prize laureate (b. 1913)

entities.title: Nobel Prize in Literature
entities.description: The Nobel Prize in Literature is a Swedish literature prize that is awarded annually, since 1901, to an author from any country who has, in the words of the will of Swedish industrialist Alfred Nobel, "in the field of literature, produced the most outstanding work in an idealistic direction". Though individual works are sometimes cited as being particularly noteworthy, the award is based on an aut

heading: Deaths
txt: Kasey Rogers, American actress (b. 1925)

entities.title: Kasey Rogers
entities.description: Kasey Rogers was an American actress, memoirist and writer, best known for playing the second Louise Tate in the popular U.S. television sitcom Bewitched.

heading: Deaths
txt: Kathleen E. Woodiwiss, American author (b. 1939)

entities.title: Kathleen E. Woodiwiss
entities.description: Kathleen E. Woodiwiss, was an American novelist. She pioneered the historical romance genre with the 1972 publication of her novel The Flame and the Flower.

heading: Deaths
txt: Vasily Aksyonov, Russian author and academic (b. 1932)

entities.title: Vasily Aksyonov
entities.description: Vasily Pavlovich Aksyonov was a Soviet and Russian novelist. He became known in the West as the author of The Burn and of Generations of Winter, a family saga following three generations of the Gradov family between 1925 and 1953.

heading: Deaths
txt: Robert McNamara, American businessman and politician, 8th United States Secretary of Defense (b. 1916)

entities.title: United States Secretary of Defense
entities.description: The United States secretary of defense (SecDef) is the leader and chief executive officer of the United States Department of Defense, the executive department of the U.S. Armed Forces. The secretary of defense's position of command and authority over the military is second only to that of the president of the United States, who is the commander-in-chief. This position corresponds to what is genera

heading: Deaths
txt: Harvey Fuqua, American singer-songwriter and producer (b. 1929)

entities.title: Harvey Fuqua
entities.description: Harvey Fuqua was an American rhythm and blues singer, songwriter, record producer, and record label executive.

heading: Deaths
txt: Carly Hibberd, Australian road racing cyclist (b. 1985)

entities.title: Carly Hibberd
entities.description: Carly Hibberd was an Australian professional road racing cyclist who competed in Union Cycliste Internationale (UCI)-sanctioned races. She won the 2008 Australian National Criterium Championships and was second in that year's Tour de Perth. Aged six, Hibberd took up BMX before moving onto mountain biking and then road cycling.through a talent identification scheme. She began riding competitive eve

heading: Deaths
txt: Hani al-Hassan, Palestinian engineer and politician (b. 1939)

entities.title: Hani al-Hassan
entities.description: Hani al Hassan, also known as, was a leader of the Fatah organization in Germany and member of the Palestinian Authority Cabinet and the Palestinian National Council.

heading: Deaths
txt: Lo Hsing Han, Burmese businessman, co-founded Asia World (b. 1935)

entities.title: Lo Hsing Han
entities.description: Lo Hsing Han or Law Sit Han was a Myanmar businessman and drug trafficker. He later became a major Myanma business tycoon, with financial ties to Singapore. He was an ethnic Kokang-Chinese. His spouse, Zhang Xiaowen, is a Chinese citizen and native of Gengma County in Yunnan.

entities.title: Asia World
entities.description: Asia World Group is a Burmese conglomerate. It is Myanmar's largest and most diversified conglomerate, with interests in industrial development, construction, transportation, import-export, and a local supermarket chain. About half of Singapore's investment in Myanmar comes from Asia World affiliates.

heading: Deaths
txt: Alan J. Dixon, American soldier, lawyer, and politician, 34th Illinois Secretary of State (b. 1927)

entities.title: Alan J. Dixon
entities.description: Alan John Dixon was an American politician and member of the Democratic Party who served in the Illinois General Assembly from 1951 to 1971, as the Illinois Treasurer from 1971 to 1977, as the Illinois Secretary of State from 1977 to 1981 and as a U.S. Senator from 1981 until 1993.

entities.title: Illinois Secretary of State
entities.description: The Secretary of State of Illinois is one of the six elected executive state offices of the government of Illinois, and one of the 47 secretaries of states in the United States. The Illinois Secretary of State keeps the state records, laws, library, and archives, and is the state's corporation registration, vehicle registration and driver licensing authority. The current Secretary of State is Jess

heading: Deaths
txt: Jerry Weintraub, American film producer, and talent agent (b. 1937)

entities.title: Jerry Weintraub
entities.description: Jerome Charles Weintraub was an American film producer, talent manager and actor whose television films won him three Emmys.

heading: Deaths
txt: Shoko Asahara, founder of Japanese cult group Aum Shinrikyo (b. 1955)

entities.title: Shoko Asahara
entities.description: Shoko Asahara , born Chizuo Matsumoto , was the founder and leader of the Japanese doomsday cult known as Aum Shinrikyo. He was convicted of masterminding the deadly 1995 sarin-gas attack on the Tokyo subway, and was also involved in several other crimes. Asahara was sentenced to death in 2004. In May 2012, his execution was postponed due to further arrests of Aum members. He was executed by hangi

entities.title: Aum Shinrikyo
entities.description: Aleph , formerly Aum Shinrikyo , is a Japanese doomsday cult and terrorist organisation founded by Shoko Asahara in 1984. It carried out the deadly Tokyo subway sarin attack in 1995 and was found to have been responsible for the Matsumoto sarin attack the previous year.

heading: Deaths
txt: Cameron Boyce, American actor

entities.title: Cameron Boyce
entities.description: Cameron Mica Boyce was an American actor. He began his career as a child actor, appearing in the 2008 films Mirrors and Eagle Eye, along with the comedy film Grown Ups (2010) and its 2013 sequel. His first starring role was on the Disney Channel comedy series Jessie (2011–2015).

heading: Deaths
txt: João Gilberto, Brazilian singer-songwriter and guitarist, pioneer of bossa nova music style (b. 1931)

entities.title: Bossa nova
entities.description: Bossa nova is a style of samba developed in the late 1950s and early 1960s in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. It is mainly characterized by "different beat" that altered the harmonies with the introduction of unconventional chords and an innovative syncopation of traditional samba from a single rhythmic division. Therefore, the "bossa nova beat", then, is characteristic of a samba style and not of an auto

heading: Deaths
txt: Charlie Daniels, American singer-songwriter, fiddle-player and guitarist (b. 1936)

entities.title: Charlie Daniels
entities.description: Charles Edward Daniels was an American singer, songwriter and multi-instrumentalist known for his contributions to Southern rock, country, and bluegrass music. He was best known for his number-one country hit "The Devil Went Down to Georgia". Much of his output, including all but one of his eight Billboard Hot 100 charting singles, was credited to the Charlie Daniels Band.

heading: Deaths
txt: Mary Kay Letourneau, American child rapist

heading: Deaths
txt: Ennio Morricone, Italian composer, orchestrator, conductor, and trumpet player (b. 1928)
